reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Excuse me, I'd like <vocabulary>to inquire</vocabulary> about Chairman Kaga. <reading>Ooh! Kaga</reading> (うかが). How exciting! You're asking questions about Chairman Kaga, the ruler over the Iron Chef kingdom.
I'm going <vocabulary>to invade</vocabulary> your country, <reading>oka</reading>y (おか)? Sorry about that, but everything will be <reading>oka</reading>y when I'm done.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

It turns out she is a <vocabulary>fake</vocabulary>. Your <reading>niece</reading> (にせ) was a robot this whole time, just pretending to be your niece. What is wrong with this world, where your niece can be an <vocabulary>imitation</vocabulary> niece. A 偽niece, if you will.
Someone tries <vocabulary>to lie</vocabulary> to you. You can't believe it. <reading>It's wha</reading>t (いつわ)??? You can't believe it.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 充電.

The reading for 冬 is the on'yomi reading, and one you haven't learned before. You're going to want to think about how you are celebrating the <vocabulary>winter solstice</vocabulary> in one particular place, that place being <reading>とう</reading>きょう. See the Tokyo landmarks around you, think that you are there on the winter solstice, and also think about the things you are doing to celebrate, here in Tokyo. Also, watch out for the rendaku.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The most <vocabulary>amazing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>terrible</vocabulary> thing you've ever seen is <reading>Su</reading>it <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (すご). Godzilla was wearing a nice suit (amazing!) but also destroying your home, your friends, and your family (terrible!).
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

You never wrap things once, you always wrap them twice. And then you double that. It's a <reading>two two</reading> (つつ) wrapping technique.

つつむ is the reading we want you to focus on, but it's good to know that 包む can be read as くるむ as well. くるむ is used when you wrap something up carefully and protectively, like a baby in a blanket. つつむ on the other hand, has broader use and is commonly used for wrapping things like presents.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
My <vocabulary>noisy</vocabulary> mom has earned the nickname <reading>yak-a-Ma</reading> (やかま). "Yakka yakka yakka," is what my mom says about my life choices.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned with reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

This is a combination of the kun'yomi readings, one of which you haven't seen yet. You'll usually see this word without the 吐 kanji, as in 嘘つき, but for now let's learn its kanji reading! 

You can't just tell one <vocabulary>lie</vocabulary>, it always turns into <reading>two</reading> (つ). Kind of like a chip or pretzel, you can't just have one. With lies, you have to open your mouth for two more. And then two more.... and... well you get it.

You didn't learn this reading of 夏 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help:

Just think about how cute little <reading>ge</reading>ckos (げ) start to come out into the open during the summer solstice. It's too cold for them to be out in the open before that, so if you look outside at the right time, you'll see geckos popping out of the ground all over the place!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading for 帰 is the on'yomi reading, which you haven't learned. Just think about how when you return to your hometown, you're going to need a <reading>key</reading> (き) to get into your old home, which you haven't been to in a long time.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 御免. The addition is all kana.
The reading for the 御 is お, the rest is てあらい, even though the い isn't showing on the end. It gets pushed into the 洗い.
The reading comes from the one you learned with the kanji. Look out for the shortening on this one.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 底 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Thoroughness</vocabulary> is important when you're making <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots. Each tater has to be cut carefully into little pieces then smashed back together again. Don't even get me started on the <vocabulary>completeness</vocabulary> I feel when I finish and eat them. Mm.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

One reading comes from 思う, so that's all good. 遣り has a weird alternate reading, though (やり). To remember it, just think about how much <vocabulary>consideration</vocabulary> you're always showing. You're always like "<reading>Yah</reading> (や), yah, no, I totally understand. SOOO sad." /end sympathy/
The readings are the respective vocab readings of 手 and 甲.
For example, <reading>yo</reading>gurt is due to milk. If milk didn't exist, neither would yogurt.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You make a <vocabulary>fist</vocabulary>. Why? Because she stole your corn on the cob. "<reading>Cob! She</reading> (こぶし) stole my cob!"
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But 拳 doesn't use the one you learned, it uses げん instead. Just imagine someone clenching their fist at you. You gulp and say げん instead of けん out of fear.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, good for you!

While こきょう is the more common reading for this word, it can also be read as ふるさと, which is a native Japanese word that originally didn't have kanji. ふるさと is also common in hiragana.
The reading comes from 早い and the reading you learned for 瀬.

This is the kun'yomi reading twice. You learned this reading when you learned 渋い. If you remember that, you know this too!

The reading for 渋 comes from 渋い. The reading for 谷 is one that shows up mostly in place names and surnames, so maybe you haven't seen it yet. To remember it, just imagine someone asking you if <vocabulary>Shibuya</vocabulary> is cool. Your answer of course is "<reading>yah</reading>" (や).
<reading>He so</reading> (ひそ) hidden. Where you at?

I'm gonna put <vocabulary>charcoal</vocabulary> in your mouth. Whatchoo gonna do? <reading>Sue me</reading> (すみ)?

The reading for 焼 and 酎 are the on'yomi readings, but you didn't learn the reading for 焼 yet. That's okay, because if you know the (also English) word <vocabulary>Shochu</vocabulary>, you'll be able to remember the reading for this one as well too.
The readings come from 甲斐 and 生き, so if you know those you may have a <vocabulary>reason for living</vocabulary>, or at least a reason for doing your kanji study.
The readings come from what you learned with the kanji. 畑 uses the shorter はた reading that you learned.
This word combines the word 甲斐 (that you already learned) with the on'yomi reading for 性. You know them both, just put them together!

The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

Note when you stick this onto a type of crop to mean a ____ <vocabulary>field</vocabulary>, this gets rendaku'd to ばたけ.
This uses the on'yomi for both kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

The 破 reading is the one you learned, the 片 reading isn't one you've learned. Just think about how you're tearing off pieces of a <reading>hen</reading> (へん), one fragment at a time. Here little chicken, I want another feather from you please. *CAW*

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that 祝 is read as しゅう for this one and you'll be fine.
The reading is the same as 群れ, so if you know that you can flock together the two memories in your brain.

What’s the key <vocabulary>to arrive at</vocabulary> enlightenment? Being an avid <reading>eater</reading> (いた)! Being an eater of all things delicious will truly let your body and mind arrive at new levels. Give it a shot. Become an eater.

The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That's honey, baby!

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that 拠 is using the こ reading you learned, not the きょ one. Just remember that you can never trust the word of a 子 (こ), so you always require them to provide <vocabulary>physical evidence</vocabulary>.

<vocabulary>Sincerity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>truth</vocabulary> are so important to me that I always keep them inside <reading>my coat</reading> (まこと). That's where I keep everything that's dearest to me, and what could be more important that sincerity and truth? Where do you keep sincerity and truth? I bet your answer is "my coat" too.

The reading for 郷 is the one you learned, but the reading for 里 isn't the one you learned. To remember this reading, just think about how your <vocabulary>birthplace</vocabulary> is the place you were <reading>rea</reading>red (り), and you <reading>rea</reading>lly (り) miss the place.

The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you might expect. Try to use the meaning mnemonic to get the meaning, then know that it sounds something similar to the reading. "Hon(g) Kon(g)" goes to <reading>ほんこん</reading>. Almost the same, right?
The reading comes from 高い and the reading you learned for 瀬.
The readings are the kun'yomi readings, but they're also the readings you learned with the kanji. Watch out for the rendaku.
